review.title: A Diversified Multi-Start Algorithm for Unconstrained Binary Quadratic Problems Leveraging the Graphics Processor Unit
review.abstract: Multi-start algorithms are a common and effective tool for metaheuristic searches. In this paper we amplify multi-start capabilities by employing the parallel processing power of the graphics processer unit (GPU) to quickly generate a diverse starting set of solutions for the Unconstrained Binary Quadratic Optimization Problem which are evaluated and used to implement screening methods to select solutions for further optimization. This method is implemented as an initial high quality solution generation phase prior to a secondary steepest ascent search and a comparison of results to best known approaches on benchmark unconstrained binary quadratic problems demonstrates that GPU-enabled diversified multi-start with screening quickly yields very good results.
histories: Quality solutions quickly obtained for xQx using the GPU to perform matrix multiplication, however improvements to solution intensification are needed

metadata.title: A Diversified Multi-Start Algorithm for Unconstrained Binary Quadratic Problems Leveraging the Graphics Processor Unit

sections.text: Multi-start algorithms are a common and effective tool for metaheuristic searches. In this paper, we extend multi-start capabilities by using the parallel processing power of the graphics processing unit (GPU) to quickly generate a diverse set of solutions to the problem of unrestricted binary quadratic optimization, which is evaluated and used to implement screening methods to select solutions for further optimizations. This method is implemented as the first high-quality solution generation phase before a secondary search for the steepest ascent, and a comparison of the results with the most common approaches to unrestricted binary quadratic problems shows that a diversified multi-start with screening quickly yields very good results.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: However, when the objective function is complex, numerous evaluations of the objective function contribute significantly to the temporal complexity of a search algorithm. One approach to reducing the temporal complexity of a combinatorial solution space is to implement a screening technique to search only those neighborhoods that are expected to provide high-quality solutions.A significant improvement has recently been made available to address these two themes.The Compute Unified Device Architecture (CUDA) is a parallel computing platform and a programming model to leverage the power of the Graphics Processor Unit (GPU).This parallel computing power can drastically reduce the time required for objective function evaluation and is particularly beneficial as the problem size increases. An advantage of the ability to quickly evaluate large sample spaces is the ability to calculate effective objective function evaluation.

sections.heading: Literature Survey
sections.text: The early work with UBQP was enabled by NVIDIA to allow software developers to access the power of their PUs. The physical problems of finding basic states of spin glasses with external magnetic fields are now used by many other computers. Subsequently, the basic problems of searching for basic states of spin glasses with external magnetic fields are investigated with different application areas such as data sharing (Alidaee, et al., 2005) and machine planning (Alidaee, et al., 2005) The GPU is a multi-processor specializing in manipulated large blocks of data using, for example, 2880 cores. In contrast, the CPU specializes in general implementations of natural speech pseudo-codes that allow different logic flows, for example, 4 cores. The CUDA platform was provided by NVIDIA to allow software developers to access the power of their PUs and many of them.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: The GPU enables rapid evaluation of objective functions using matrix multiplication. This capability enables the generation of a large number of multistarts and screening for initial easy optimization. In this paper, it was found that this approach very quickly generated high-quality solutions for two sets of benchmark UBQP, but generally found no best-known solutions. Therefore, the approach may place too much emphasis on diversifying the search and not enough on intensifying or improving the solution.
